Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(2) Summary

API Governance becomes increasingly challenging with increasing organizational size: How to best balance the needs of faster ways of developing products with the needs of an organization that has to manage many of these products? Pillar #1 of API Governance are insights: In order to understand where the API landscape is moving, it is important to understand what it looks like. Pillar #2 of API Governance are interfaces: APIs are saying that how things are built is of no concern to a capability's user, but that what is being built can make a big difference in terms of how APIs are discovered and used. Pillar #3 of API Governance is nudging: The most effective way to evolve API landscapes is when teams make all the right design and implementation decisions by themselves. Using these three pillars of API governance, enterprise architects and platform teams can have a substantial and productive influence on an organization's API landscape.

Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(7) The World is Changing Faster

  • Existing value chains may be challenged and must adapt
  • Global connectivity enables new opportunities to scale
  • A networked economy creates many network effects
  • Changing markets require changes in products and value propositions


Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(8) Linear Business Models



Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(9) The Platform Business Model



Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(10) But … We're not Google

  • Pure platforms are more the exception than the norm
  • Linear business models can be augmented with platform ideas
  • Creating hybrid models can make a big difference
    • Opportunity to scale because the platform part attracts consumers
    • Ability to differentiate in an increasingly commoditized market
    • Decreasing risk because of more feedback and ability to adapt


Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(11) Hybrid Linear/Platform Business Models



Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(12) Platformize Yourself

  • Consider new value chains based on platform business models
  • Open and evolve your platform to open everything that you have
  • Everything you build becomes part of your platform

(14) API Visibility: Inside-Out vs. Outside-In



Insights: API the APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(15) API Descriptions: Labeling APIs [http://dret.net/lectures/api-days-paris-2019/]

  • APIs can be described in a variety of ways
    • Technical descriptions for interface mechanics (e.g., OpenAPI [https://www.openapis.org/] and AsyncAPI [https://www.asyncapi.com/])
    • Documentation intended for human consumption
    • Metadata helping with API lifecycle management (e.g., APIs.json [http://apisjson.org/] and schema.org [https://schema.org/WebAPI])
  • API description requirements
    • Be independent of API technology and implementation
    • Define an evolving set of well-known elements
    • Provide openness for custom additions
    • Support existing formats for backwards-compatibility
    • Build on existing patterns and specifications for description on the Web


Insights: API the APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

Interfaces: What over How Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(19) Constraints > Rules

  • Aim for the minimal number of constraints for your API landscape
    • Minimizing constraints maximizes the freedom of teams
    • Revisit existing constraints and remove/relax them when possible
  • Look at rules as suggestions how to satisfy constraints
    • Help teams to satisfy constraints if they want/need help
    • Try to make rules optional whenever possible


Interfaces: What over How Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(20) APIs for Loose Coupling

  • Teams communicate through their API dependencies
    • Avoid hidden dependencies like shared libraries
  • There are no shortcuts: APIs are the only way to create dependencies
    • API stories help with the design of product APIs
  • Implementation details and concerns are never made visible
    • Implementation changes can be done safely


Interfaces: What over How Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(24) Nudging in Ecosystems



Nudging: Engineering the Engineers Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(25) API Guidelines as Shared Practices

  • More API teams mean more ways to solve the same problem
    • Solving API problems is not what teams should focus on
    • Solving API problems in a consistent way helps the API landscape
  • Communications across teams is a challenge
    • Complement channels with documentation of practices


Nudging: Engineering the Engineers Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(26) The Anatomy of a Good Guideline

  • Why does the guideline exist?
    • Rationale for creating the guideline
  • What can be done to address the described issue
    • At least one good solution for addressing the issue
  • How to implement the solution
    • At least one way to use the solution in practice
  • Testing that the guideline has been followed
    • Some tests can be automated but many will be by declaration or review


Nudging: Engineering the Engineers Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(27) API Guideline Example



Nudging: Engineering the Engineers Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(28) API Guidelines in the Wild



Nudging: Engineering the Engineers Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(29) Getting Started

  • Start capturing feedback from API teams
    • Challenges along the way
    • Solutions they have found or implemented
    • Quantifying the time they spend with cross-cutting vs. domain tasks
  • Start editing and providing guidance that API teams can find and use
    • Tooling can be as simple as markdown and shared repositories


Conclusions

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance

(31) Doing APIs Right

  • APIs create most value in decentralized scenarios
  • Support decentralization but be aware of patterns and practices
  • Align API design to improve coherence across the landscape
  • Create incentives that make it easy to do the right thing


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): The Three Pillars of API Governance
